text: Meanwhile I feel cheated having to take on new mental models and run them in my head. While computers are great at simulating physical systems, we're ironically stuck having to mentally simulate computers themselves.

elements.text: Meanwhile I feel cheated having to take on new mental models and run them in my head. While computers are great at simulating physical systems, we're ironically stuck having to mentally simulate computers themselves.

text:
The section on domain specific languages resonated with me. When there's a specific domain, it's easier to think of ways to make tasks in that domain easier.

"the allure of programming language research, that the tools and theories we develop don’t affect just a single domain, but potentially everybody who programs"

If domain-specific languages were more composable, maybe work can be done to gradually make each domain easier while still allowing a general purpose program to be constructed from those parts?

text: Thanks for sharing! <http://westoncb.blogspot.com/2015/06/why-programming-languages-dont-have.html?m=1> was interesting. I think he makes a good argument for why we should use graphs to represent programs. Are you aware of any work to standardize on such a graph format? <@UD4Q9LT52> presented one at one of the Strangeloop 2018 meetups that runs with this idea. He decided to use labeled edges so that things like type graphs and data dependencies can be represented in the same graph structure.

elements.text: was interesting. I think he makes a good argument for why we should use graphs to represent programs. Are you aware of any work to standardize on such a graph format?

presented one at one of the Strangeloop 2018 meetups that runs with this idea. He decided to use labeled edges so that things like type graphs and data dependencies can be represented in the same graph structure.

text:
> all the language needs is a unique identifier, so we just generate a random one

Jake used that idea in his demo, too. Generate Guids for nodes. This makes names for variables unnecessary, but could still be added as documentation.
